column14: Answer

column3: A network is a collection of computers
column4: servers
column7: and other devices connected to one another to share data
column14: A network is a collection of computers  servers  mainframes  network devices  and other devices connected to one another to share data  resources  and services.

column2: What are the types of networks?
column3: The types of networks include LAN (Local Area Network)
column4: WAN (Wide Area Network)
column14: The types of networks include LAN (Local Area Network)  WAN (Wide Area Network)  MAN (Metropolitan Area Network)  and WLAN (Wireless Local Area Network).

column3: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model is a conceptual framework used to understand and describe network interactions in seven layers: Physical
column4: Data Link
column14: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model is a conceptual framework used to understand and describe network interactions in seven layers: Physical  Data Link  Network  Transport  Session  Presentation  and Application.

column3: A router is a networking device that forwards data packets between computer networks
column4: often connecting a local network to the internet or to other networks.
column14: A router is a networking device that forwards data packets between computer networks  often connecting a local network to the internet or to other networks.

column3: An IP (Internet Protocol) address is a unique identifier assigned to each device connected to a network
column4: enabling communication between devices over the internet or a local network.
column14: An IP (Internet Protocol) address is a unique identifier assigned to each device connected to a network  enabling communication between devices over the internet or a local network.

column2: What is the difference between IPv4 and IPv6?
column3: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses and supports about 4 billion unique addresses
column4: while IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses
column5: supporting a vastly larger address space.
column14: IPv4 uses 32-bit addresses and supports about 4 billion unique addresses  while IPv6 uses 128-bit addresses  supporting a vastly larger address space.

column3: A subnet (subnetwork) is a logical division of an IP network into smaller networks. It helps optimize routing
column4: enhance security
column14: A subnet (subnetwork) is a logical division of an IP network into smaller networks. It helps optimize routing  enhance security  and reduce network traffic.

column3: DNS (Domain Name System) is a hierarchical system that translates human-readable domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers can understand.
column14: DNS (Domain Name System) is a hierarchical system that translates human-readable domain names (like www.example.com) into IP addresses that computers can understand.

column3: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communication within a local network. It operates at the Data Link layer of the OSI model.
column14: A MAC (Media Access Control) address is a unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communication within a local network. It operates at the Data Link layer of the OSI model.

column3: A switch is a network device that connects devices within a LAN
column4: using MAC addresses to forward data only to the device it is intended for
column14: A switch is a network device that connects devices within a LAN  using MAC addresses to forward data only to the device it is intended for  thus reducing collisions.

column3: A hub is a basic networking device that connects multiple devices in a LAN. Unlike a switch
column4: it broadcasts data to all devices on the network
column5: leading to potential collisions and inefficiencies.
column14: A hub is a basic networking device that connects multiple devices in a LAN. Unlike a switch  it broadcasts data to all devices on the network  leading to potential collisions and inefficiencies.

column2: What is the difference between a switch and a hub?
column3: A switch forwards data to the specific device it is intended for using MAC addresses
column4: while a hub broadcasts data to all connected devices
column14: A switch forwards data to the specific device it is intended for using MAC addresses  while a hub broadcasts data to all connected devices  causing unnecessary traffic and collisions.

column3: A gateway is a network device that acts as a bridge between two different networks
column4: often between a local network and the internet
column5: and is used to translate communication between different protocols.
column14: A gateway is a network device that acts as a bridge between two different networks  often between a local network and the internet  and is used to translate communication between different protocols.

column3: A firewall is a security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules. It helps protect networks from unauthorized access or attacks.
column14: A firewall is a security system that monitors and controls incoming and outgoing network traffic based on predetermined security rules. It helps protect networks from unauthorized access or attacks.

column3: NAT is a process used in networking to modify the source or destination IP address in packet headers to enable multiple devices on a local network to share a single public IP address.
column14: NAT is a process used in networking to modify the source or destination IP address in packet headers to enable multiple devices on a local network to share a single public IP address.

column3: A VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network) is a logical partition of a physical network that groups devices into a virtual network
column4: providing better security
column14: A VLAN (Virtual Local Area Network) is a logical partition of a physical network that groups devices into a virtual network  providing better security  efficiency  and traffic management.

column3: A load balancer is a device or software that distributes network traffic across multiple servers to ensure no single server is overwhelmed
column4: improving performance and reliability.
column14: A load balancer is a device or software that distributes network traffic across multiple servers to ensure no single server is overwhelmed  improving performance and reliability.

column3: A proxy server is an intermediary server that sits between a client and a destination server
column4: often used to filter requests
column6: or cache content for faster access.
column14: A proxy server is an intermediary server that sits between a client and a destination server  often used to filter requests  improve security  or cache content for faster access.

column2: What is the difference between a proxy server and a firewall?
column3: A proxy server acts as an intermediary between clients and servers
column4: while a firewall monitors and filters network traffic to enforce security policies.
column14: A proxy server acts as an intermediary between clients and servers  while a firewall monitors and filters network traffic to enforce security policies.

column2: What is an IP subnet mask?
column3: An IP subnet mask is used to divide an IP address into network and host portions
column4: helping devices identify which part of the address refers to the network and which refers to the host.
column14: An IP subnet mask is used to divide an IP address into network and host portions  helping devices identify which part of the address refers to the network and which refers to the host.

column2: What is DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)?
column3: DHCP is a network protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses to devices on a network
column4: eliminating the need for manual configuration of IP settings.
column14: DHCP is a network protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses to devices on a network  eliminating the need for manual configuration of IP settings.

column2: What is a VPN (Virtual Private Network)?
column3: A VPN is a service that creates a secure
column4: encrypted connection between a device and a remote server over the internet
column5: ensuring privacy and security while browsing or accessing a network remotely.
column14: A VPN is a service that creates a secure  encrypted connection between a device and a remote server over the internet  ensuring privacy and security while browsing or accessing a network remotely.

column3: The TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) model is a conceptual framework for communication over a network
column4: consisting of four layers: Link
column14: The TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) model is a conceptual framework for communication over a network  consisting of four layers: Link  Internet  Transport  and Application.

column2: What is the difference between TCP and UDP?
column3: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable data transmission
column4: while UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is a connectionless protocol that provides faster but less reliable communication.
column14: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a connection-oriented protocol that ensures reliable data transmission  while UDP (User Datagram Protocol) is a connectionless protocol that provides faster but less reliable communication.

column2: What is the role of ARP (Address Resolution Protocol)?
column3: ARP is a protocol used to map a 32-bit IP address to a MAC address within a local network
column4: allowing devices to find each other on a subnet.
column14: ARP is a protocol used to map a 32-bit IP address to a MAC address within a local network  allowing devices to find each other on a subnet.

column2: What is the difference between ARP and DNS?
column3: ARP maps IP addresses to MAC addresses within a local network
column4: while DNS maps human-readable domain names to IP addresses across the internet.
column14: ARP maps IP addresses to MAC addresses within a local network  while DNS maps human-readable domain names to IP addresses across the internet.

column2: What is a port in networking?
column3: A port is a logical endpoint for communication in a network
column4: identified by a number
column5: which helps direct data packets to specific applications or services on a device.
column14: A port is a logical endpoint for communication in a network  identified by a number  which helps direct data packets to specific applications or services on a device.

column3: A TCP port is an identifier for a specific service or application running on a device
column4: used by the TCP protocol to route data to the appropriate destination.
column14: A TCP port is an identifier for a specific service or application running on a device  used by the TCP protocol to route data to the appropriate destination.

column3: A UDP port is a number used by the UDP protocol to identify specific applications or services on a device. UDP ports do not ensure reliable delivery of packets like TCP.
column14: A UDP port is a number used by the UDP protocol to identify specific applications or services on a device. UDP ports do not ensure reliable delivery of packets like TCP.

column3: A collision domain is a network segment where data packets can collide with each other
column4: often occurring in older network devices like hubs. Switches reduce collision domains by forwarding data only to specific devices.
column14: A collision domain is a network segment where data packets can collide with each other  often occurring in older network devices like hubs. Switches reduce collision domains by forwarding data only to specific devices.

column3: A broadcast domain is a network segment where broadcast packets (packets sent to all devices) can be received by all devices within that segment.
column14: A broadcast domain is a network segment where broadcast packets (packets sent to all devices) can be received by all devices within that segment.

column3: SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) and TLS (Transport Layer Security) are cryptographic protocols designed to provide secure communication over a computer network
column4: commonly used for securing HTTP traffic (HTTPS).
column14: SSL (Secure Sockets Layer) and TLS (Transport Layer Security) are cryptographic protocols designed to provide secure communication over a computer network  commonly used for securing HTTP traffic (HTTPS).

column3: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is a protocol used for transferring web pages over the internet. It is an application-layer protocol in the TCP/IP model.
column14: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is a protocol used for transferring web pages over the internet. It is an application-layer protocol in the TCP/IP model.

column3: HTTPS (HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure) is the secure version of HTTP
column4: using SSL/TLS encryption to secure the data transfer between a client and a web server.
column14: HTTPS (HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure) is the secure version of HTTP  using SSL/TLS encryption to secure the data transfer between a client and a web server.

column3: ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) is used for sending error messages and operational information about network operations
column4: such as "destination unreachable" or "time exceeded" messages.
column14: ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol) is used for sending error messages and operational information about network operations  such as "destination unreachable" or "time exceeded" messages.

column3: Ping is a network utility that uses ICMP to test the reachability of a host on a network and measures the round-trip time for messages sent from the originating host to a destination.
column14: Ping is a network utility that uses ICMP to test the reachability of a host on a network and measures the round-trip time for messages sent from the originating host to a destination.

column3: Traceroute is a network diagnostic tool that traces the path data packets take from one host to another
column4: showing each hop (router) along the way and the time it takes to reach each hop.
column14: Traceroute is a network diagnostic tool that traces the path data packets take from one host to another  showing each hop (router) along the way and the time it takes to reach each hop.

column2: What is the difference between a router and a switch?
column3: A router connects different networks and routes data between them
column4: while a switch connects devices within the same network and forwards data based on MAC addresses.
column14: A router connects different networks and routes data between them  while a switch connects devices within the same network and forwards data based on MAC addresses.

column3: A DHCP lease is a temporary assignment of an IP address to a device on a network. The lease time defines how long the device can use the IP address before needing to renew it.
column14: A DHCP lease is a temporary assignment of an IP address to a device on a network. The lease time defines how long the device can use the IP address before needing to renew it.

column3: A subnet mask is used in conjunction with an IP address to define the network portion and the host portion of the address
column4: facilitating the proper routing of network traffic.
column14: A subnet mask is used in conjunction with an IP address to define the network portion and the host portion of the address  facilitating the proper routing of network traffic.

column2: What is the OSI layer responsible for error detection and correction?
column3: The Data Link layer (Layer 2) is responsible for error detection and correction
column4: ensuring that data is transmitted without errors between devices in a network.
column14: The Data Link layer (Layer 2) is responsible for error detection and correction  ensuring that data is transmitted without errors between devices in a network.

column2: What is the maximum transmission unit (MTU)?
column3: MTU refers to the largest size of a data packet that can be transmitted over a network in a single transmission without fragmentation.
column14: MTU refers to the largest size of a data packet that can be transmitted over a network in a single transmission without fragmentation.

column3: A VLAN tag is a 4-byte identifier added to an Ethernet frame to identify which VLAN the frame belongs to
column4: enabling the logical segmentation of networks.
column14: A VLAN tag is a 4-byte identifier added to an Ethernet frame to identify which VLAN the frame belongs to  enabling the logical segmentation of networks.

column2: What is a DMZ (Demilitarized Zone) in networking?
column3: A DMZ is a perimeter network that separates an internal network from external networks
column4: often used to host public-facing services like websites or mail servers while protecting the internal network from external threats.
column14: A DMZ is a perimeter network that separates an internal network from external networks  often used to host public-facing services like websites or mail servers while protecting the internal network from external threats.

column2: What is the role of a switch in a VLAN?
column3: A switch is used to segment a network into multiple VLANs by assigning different ports to different VLANs
column4: enabling better traffic management and security within a network.
column14: A switch is used to segment a network into multiple VLANs by assigning different ports to different VLANs  enabling better traffic management and security within a network.

column2: What is a hop in networking?
column3: A hop refers to the traversal of a data packet from one network device to another
column4: such as from one router to the next along the path between a source and a destination.
column14: A hop refers to the traversal of a data packet from one network device to another  such as from one router to the next along the path between a source and a destination.

column3: IPsec (Internet Protocol Security) is a suite of protocols used to secure IP communications by authenticating and encrypting each IP packet in a communication session.
column14: IPsec (Internet Protocol Security) is a suite of protocols used to secure IP communications by authenticating and encrypting each IP packet in a communication session.

column3: A VPN tunnel is an encrypted connection established between a client and a VPN server
column4: allowing private data to travel securely over a public network
column14: A VPN tunnel is an encrypted connection established between a client and a VPN server  allowing private data to travel securely over a public network  such as the internet.
